text: SAMUEL C. WORDEMAN, Ph.D a witness herein, having been first duly sworn, was examined and testified as follows: EXAMINATION
Would you state your full name and spell your last name for the Ladies and Gentlemen of the jury.
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  My name is Samuel Clayton Wordeman.  My last name is spelled W-O-R-D-E-M-A-N.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you briefly describe your educational background, where you went to school, and what degrees you obtained?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  I did my undergraduate work at Washington University in St. Louis, where I obtained a bachelor's degree in biomedical engineering with a focus on biomechanics.  And then I started my graduate work at the University of Cincinnati in a Ph.D. program for biomedical engineering and then subsequently transferred to Ohio State, where I obtained a master's degree and Ph.D. in biomedical engineering.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is biomechanics or biomedical engineering?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So as sort of an umbrella discipline, biomedical engineering is any field that utilizes the principles of engineering and physics in the context of biology and medicine.  So there are biomedical engineers who design implants and hip or knee prosthesis.  There are biomedical engineers who design surgical instrumentation. And my specific area of focus within the field of biomedical engineering is what's referred to as biomechanics.  And essentially biomechanics is a field that takes the principles of mechanical engineering, so the principles of forces and, you know, stretches and strains and applies them to, in this case, the human body. So I spent a lot of time studying the mechanical properties of the tissues of the human body and how those tissues respond to stretching or straining and application of external forces. And then another field within biomechanics is sort of what I would refer to as injury biomechanics which is the type of force, the direction of force, and the nature of force required to cause particular injuries to the human body.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What types of research have you performed in biomedical engineering?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  I have done a lot of different types of research in biomedical engineering.  When I was doing my graduate work, I worked in a lab where we had a big 3D motion analysis system, and we would actually measure the 3D motion of the human body.  So the same type of systems that you see at play when you see a Pixar movie or something where you see people with markers on their skin, and then you can track the markers in three dimensions. We use that same technology for more scientific type of analysis. I have also done a lot of research using cadavers or human tissue donations, people who have donated their bodies to science, where we'll actually take the part of the human anatomy and apply forces to it and measure the types of forces required to cause a particular injury and investigate what I would call injury mechanisms. I have also done a lot of research with regard to what I would call a computer analysis.  So we'll take the same type of analysis that we did with the cadavers or with the live subjects and we'll actually create a computer model or a 3D model in the computer to allow us to further investigate the effective various forces on the tissues of the human body. And then in addition to that type of research, I have also done crash testing research through the course of my employment with ARCCA, where I've actually measured the forces associated with automobile crashes.  And I have also done component testing of motor vehicle accidents in the context of a biomechanical analysis.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where did you go after you obtained your Ph.D.?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So shortly after I finished my graduate work, I stayed on board with Ohio State for approximately six months doing a postdoctoral research-ship, where I was essentially doing a lot of the same type of work I was doing as a graduate student, and I was also helping to get some new research projects off the ground, projects that I had helped obtain funding from the National Institutes of Health for.  And then after about six months, I went to work for a company where I am currently employed called ARCCA.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is ARCCA?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: ARCCA is an engineering consulting company.  We do a lot of different types of engineering consulting.  We have people who do purely sort of accident reconstruction type of opinions.  We have people who are structural engineers who do structural engineering. We started out as a group of naval engineers in the 1980s.  These are guys who were involved with designing ejection systems and restraint systems from naval aircraft, and then they sort of found a natural niche in the automotive world after they got out of the military and into the civilian world.  And so we have a lot of different types of engineers, but we are an engineering consulting company that does a lot of different types of work.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: With respect to ARCCA, what is your role?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: So my role is what's referred to -- my job title is a Senior Biomechanist.  So I'm in our biomechanics department, and my job is essentially to evaluate the safety of restraint systems and to perform what I would call biomechanical engineering causation analyses in automotive or occupational settings.  And -- so essentially I investigate injury mechanisms.  I investigate the types of forces associated with various incidents. And then I also do some work with the National Hockey League, making recommendations as to the safety of their equipment.  So, generally speaking, I'm involved in identifying the safety of various systems and identifying the potential for injury due to various circumstances.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you published any of the results of your research endeavors?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.  I have about 22 publications to date, I believe.  Generally speaking, they all involve some sort of injury mechanism identification or identification of risk of injury.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever presented your research to groups of other engineering professionals?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes; I have presented numerous times at the national level, numerous national conferences as well as some smaller conferences.  I've also been fortunate enough to receive recognition in the form of awards from national organizations for some of the research that I have done. So, yeah, I have presented on the national stage multiple times.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you a medical doctor?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No, sir, I'm not a medical doctor.  And sort of the main difference between what I do and what a medical doctor does is a medical doctor is trained in order to identify and diagnose injuries and then put forth a treatment plan to help a patient recover from those injuries. My training really is in specifically understanding how those injuries occur in the first place. So I don't treat or diagnose patients.  I am essentially interested in the forces required to cause the injuries in the first place.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: With respect to your work in this case, are you contesting any of the diagnoses that were made by any of Ms. Perez's treating physicians?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No, sir, certainly not.  As I mentioned, that -- really the diagnosis falls under the purview of the medical doctors and that's what they're trained to do.  So certainly actually accepting those diagnoses as fact is sort of the first step in my analysis.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you previously been qualified to give testimony in courts regarding the same topics you're here to testify about today?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir; I have been qualified to testify in courts in New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, and Illinois.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And has your testimony ever been precluded or barred in any court?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No, it has not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Objection.  Relevancy.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Doctor, I'm going to show you what has been marked as Exhibit No. 1 with today's date for identification purposes.  Can you identify that document?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.  This is my professional biographical outline or my CV.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Does that set forth your education, your training, your employment, your publications, and your professional accomplishments?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is it true and accurate?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any additions, deletions, or changes you would like to make to that document?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No, sir.  It's up to date.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At this time we would offer Exhibit No. 1, Defendant's Exhibit No. 1 into evidence.
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: (Defendant's Exhibit No. 1 was offered into evidence.)
Doctor, what were you asked to do in this case?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: I was asked to perform what's referred to as a biomechanical injury causation analysis.  So essentially that is an analysis to determine whether or not a particular injury or set of injuries could have been physically caused by the circumstances in this case of the motor vehicle accident on May 28th of 2015.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you explain for the jury how that is different from a medical doctor's diagnoses?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So essentially the medical doctors identify the symptoms and come to a conclusion with regard to what the injuries are, based on medical imaging or a history. What I do is actually analyze the circumstances of the motor vehicle accident in this case and determine whether or not the forces present in that motor vehicle accident and the forces applied to the plaintiff's body are consistent with the injuries that are being attributed to that particular incident.  So it's a very different and in my opinion more robust type of analysis than a diagnosis.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is involved in a biomedical or biomechanical injury causation analysis?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So my analysis consists of five steps.  As I mentioned previously, the first step in that analysis is to identify the injuries that are being attributed to the motor vehicle accident.  And as I mentioned, I'm not a medical doctor, so I'm not coming up with these diagnoses on my own.  That particular step really consists of reviewing the medical records and identifying what diagnoses the medical doctors offer. The next step in the analysis is to determine the severity of the motor vehicle accident, so essentially how bad of a motor vehicle accident was this.  What were the -- there are sort of two numbers that I'm primarily interested in.  Those would be what I would call the Delta-V and the accelerations in the accident, and I'll get into more depth on those a little bit later here. The next step after I've identified or quantified the severity of the accident is to determine the kinematic response of the plaintiff.  And when I say "kinematic response," what I mean is I'm looking at the way that the plaintiff would have moved relative to the interior of the vehicle, in this case the 2004 Chevrolet Malibu, and I'm analyzing her interactions with the vehicle and the motion that she would have experienced as a result of the motor vehicle accident. And then the next step is to determine whether or not that movement of her body and the interaction between her body and the interior of the vehicle would have created what I would refer to as the injury mechanism responsible for the injury being claimed.  And when I say "injury mechanism," I'm talking about the types of forces, so the direction of force, as well as the magnitude of force needed in order to physically damage the anatomical structures that are being claimed to have been injured in this particular accident. And then the final step is to take into account the plaintiff's specific circumstances and the individual tolerance of the plaintiff to the types of forces that she experienced in this particular accident, and to analyze those forces in the context of the types of forces that she would have experienced on a daily basis doing fairly benign tasks that are generally not associated with injury.  So that's sort of the five-step analysis that I performed in this particular case.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What materials were you provided in reference to this case?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.  I was provided with a number of materials, and then I also generated a number of materials during the course of my analysis.  But I was provided with the police report, the Illinois Traffic Crash Report, as well as color and black and white photographs of both of the vehicles, the 2004 Chevrolet Malibu and the 2015 Toyota Rav4.  I also had the repair estimate for the 2004 Chevrolet Malibu as well as a prior damage report for the same vehicle, the 2004 Chevrolet Malibu.  I had the medical records for the plaintiff, Ms. Perez, both prior to and subsequent to the motor vehicle accident.  I had the interrogatories from the plaintiff, as well as the deposition transcript of both Ms. Martinez, the defendant, as well as Ms. Perez, the plaintiff, and then I had deposition transcripts of three medical doctors, Dr. Michael Lee, Dr. Matthew Bueche, B-U-E-C-H-E, and Dr. Asavari Javeri, J-A-V-E-R-I.  And those were the materials that were provided to me by your office, and then I also generated some materials during the course of my analysis, including specification sheets for the vehicles involved an analyses of the severity of the accident and numerous scientific references to support the opinions that I have in this case.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that your file to your right?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: After you completed your review of all of those materials, you did your analysis, did you prepare a report?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir, I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm going to show you what has been marked as Exhibit No. -- Defendant's Exhibit No. 2 for identification purposes.  Is it a true and accurate copy of your report?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir, it is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would it be helpful for you to review either your file or your report while testifying here today?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir, it may.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Please feel free to do so if it helps you. Generally speaking, after reviewing the materials we've discussed, how would you describe the subject incident?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So after reviewing all of the available materials, it appears that on May 28th of 2015 Ms. Emilie Perez was the seat-belted driver of a 2004 Chevrolet Malibu.  All of the materials indicate that that vehicle was stopped facing northbound on South Ewing Avenue in Chicago, Illinois. Ms. Martinez was the driver of a 2015 Toyota Rav4, and as the Chevrolet was stopped, at some point there was contact between the front of the 2015 Rav4 and the rear of the 2004 Chevrolet Malibu.  And then according to the testimony of the plaintiff, there was subsequently a contact between the front of her vehicle and an unidentified vehicle in front of her at some point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, with respect to the contact between the front of Ms. Perez's Chevy Malibu and the vehicle in front of her, was there any mention of that in the police report?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No, sir, not that I identified.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Object.  I would like to put on an objection of beyond 213.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Was there any mention of that in the deposition of Ms. Martinez?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there any mention of a frontal collision in any of the medical records that you reviewed?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said the first step in your five-step analysis was to identify the injuries.  What did you do to identify the injuries in this particular case?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So as I mentioned, that essentially consists of reviewing the plaintiff's medical records and identifying what the medical doctors say the diagnosed injuries were.  So I reviewed the plaintiff's medical records and identified that she was diagnosed with spondylolisthesis of L5 on S1, which essentially means that the 5th lumbar vertebra which is sort of the big bone in the lumbar spine was diagnosed as having been shifted forward relative to her sacrum or essentially her tailbone which is the lowest part of the lumbosacral spine.  So she was diagnosed with that, and then she had a previous diagnosis of what I would call a spondylolysis or a pars defect which is basically damage to the bones located at the posterior aspect of her lumbar spine.  And those two diagnoses were essentially related to one another, according to all of the medical doctors.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Move to strike, pending motions in limine, beyond 213.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Doctor, in terms of medical training, did you complete medical school?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No, sir.  As I mentioned, I don't have a medical degree.  I do have training.  I took courses in physiology and human anatomy at the University of Cincinnati Medical School as sort of part of my initial training as a graduate student in biomedical engineering.  And so those are the same courses taken by the medical doctors at the University of Cincinnati or the medical students at the University of Cincinnati. And then as I mentioned, after those initial base work courses, myself and my engineering colleagues went on to study the forces required to cause damage to the human anatomy and the structures that make up the human body, whereas my colleagues in medical school went on to study how to identify what those injuries are and how to diagnose those injuries.  So I certainly do have training in what I would consider the medical field, but I don't have a medical degree.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: With respect to spondylolysis and spondylolisthesis, are those diagnoses that were made by Ms. Perez's physicians?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Objection.  Beyond 213.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: And you know that from reviewing the medical records and the depositions?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is the mechanisms for a traumatic spondylolisthesis?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So as I mentioned --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Objection.  Objection.  Objection, pending motions in limine.  Beyond 213.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: So the mechanisms required to cause spondylolisthesis requires shear force applied to the lumbar spine.  As I mentioned, spondylolisthesis refers to relative movement of the bones in the lumbar spine.  In this case, relative movement forward of the fifth or the lowest lumbar vertebra relative to the sacrum.  So the mechanism required to cause that in a traumatic type of setting would require what I would refer to as a shear force applied to L5, pushing L5 forward relative to the sacrum.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Motion to strike as to the medical opinion.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Now, the second step you had to determine the severity of the accident.  What does that mean?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So essentially that is how bad of a motor vehicle accident was this.  And as I mentioned previously, the -- that really consists of identifying sort of two numbers; the first number is what I would refer to as the Delta-V, and that's basically the change in velocity or the change in speed of the vehicle as a result of the collision.  So to illustrate that point, if you were at a stop sign and your vehicle was stopped and then somebody were to come up behind you and contact the rear of your vehicle, and your vehicle was, say, at the end of the accident moving forward approximately 5 miles per hour, that will be a 5-mile-per-hour Delta-V.  The same thing if your vehicle was going 10 miles per hour and somebody struck you in the rear and you were rear-ended, and at the end of that accident your vehicle was going 15 miles an hour, that would also be a 5-mile-per-hour Delta-V.  So it's -- the Delta-V is how much your vehicle changes its speed as a result of the collision. But if you think about it, you know, you could be stopped at a stop sign and you could depress the accelerator in your vehicle and also go from 0 to 5 miles per hour, but that is a different scenario from the rear-end collision that I talked about.  The main difference there is that your vehicle would go from 0 to 5 miles per hour during a rear-end collision over the course of about one to two-tenths of a second, whereas if you were applying the accelerator, it would take quite a bit longer.  And so the quicker that your vehicle experiences that Delta-V, the higher the acceleration is associated with that Delta-V.  So that's what I would refer to as the G forces or the accelerations which are the second number that I attempt to identify when I perform a severity analysis.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What are the steps that you look -- that you took to determine the severity of the accident?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So in any motor vehicle accident the first thing that I want to do is identify the vehicles involved in the motor vehicle accident.  So I use the vehicle identification numbers to identify the year, makes and models of those vehicles.  And then I utilize that information to identify specifications for those vehicles, so things like dimensions and weights of the vehicle. Next I generally in a case like this where you have bumper-to-bumper contact will identify the components that make up the bumper systems of those two vehicles, and then I'll utilize the laws of physics and accepted engineering methodologies or accident reconstruction methodologies to assess the damages to those two vehicles and use that information to come up with numbers for the Delta-V and the accelerations as we talked about previously.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you briefly tell the jury what you found with regard to the bumper assemblies on each of the vehicles?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So the bumper assembly on the 2004 Chevrolet Malibu consists of a steel reenforcement bar which is mounted to the rear body of the vehicle, and then there is a foam energy absorber.  So it's sort of a dense foam component that's called the energy absorber, and that sits between that steel reenforcement bar and the plastic bumper cover or what you actually see on the outside of the vehicle. And the vehicle, the 2015 Toyota Rav4, utilizes a similar type of bumper system.  There is an energy absorber and then there is a reenforcement bar that has mounting brackets attached to it, and those mounting brackets attach to the frame of the vehicle.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What was the damage to the plaintiff's vehicle?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So the plaintiff's vehicle had damage to the rear bumper assembly, so the components that we talked about that make up the bumper assembly as well as the rear body panel and the trunk lid.  And so that was essentially the damaged components of the plaintiff's vehicle in this case.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What was your final conclusion with regard to the severity of the accident?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So in this case I determined that the Delta-V in this particular case for the rear-end collision would have been less than 6.75 miles per hour and the accelerations associated with that rear-end Delta-V would have been less than 1.8g's average.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you explain to the jury how you came to those numbers?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  In this case I performed what's referred to as a damage-based speed change analysis.  And essentially what that is, is a damage-to-damage comparison between the plaintiff's vehicle and a vehicle that was subjected to a low-speed rear-end crash test.  So in this case I had low-speed rear-end crash test for a 2004 Chevrolet Malibu that demonstrated greater structural damage to that Chevrolet Malibu than was sustained to the plaintiff's vehicle.  Specifically the vehicle in the rear -- low-speed rear-end crash test sustained damage not only to the rear bumper assembly, but also to the rear unibody or what I would essentially call the frame of the vehicle as well as to the frame side member ends.  So those are really the stiffest sort of structural components of the rear of the vehicle and damage to the rear body panel and the rear floor pan.  So there was more energy imparted to that vehicle that was tested by the IIHS, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, than there was damage to the plaintiff's vehicle.  And as a result, I concluded that the plaintiff's vehicle experienced a Delta-V that was less than that sustained by the tested vehicle.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So the vehicle in the test was a 2004 Chevy Malibu which is the same type of car that was driven by Ms. Perez?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And in that particular case they measured an actual Delta-V of 6.75?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the Chevy in that particular test had more damage than the Chevy involved in this accident?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Right, and it's more structural damage.  So, you know, damage to a tail lamp or something like that doesn't necessarily indicate a great deal of energy imparted to the vehicle.  We're talking about structural damage.  So this is damage to the strong structural steel components of the vehicle that we are talking about.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you saying the Delta-V of the plaintiff's vehicle in this case was 6.75 miles per hour?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No, sir.  It was less than 6.75 miles per hour.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, with respect to the vehicle involved in this particular case, I sent over Exhibits 3 through 12.  And do those photographs depict the Toyota driven by my client, Ms. Martinez?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And likewise, I'm going to show you real quickly what was marked as Defendant's Exhibits 14 through 22. And do those photographs depict the vehicle that was being driven by Mrs. Perez -- or Ms. Perez?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, with respect to the damage to the rear of the Chevy Malibu, as part of your analysis, did you work on the assumption that all of that damage was from this accident?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: All of the rear-end damage, yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would it be fair to say that your analysis takes into account a much more severe scenario than the severity of the actual incident?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Objection to the form.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Yes.  I want to give the plaintiff the benefit of the doubt with regard to how severe this accident was.  And so essentially I would prefer to overestimate the severity of the accident as opposed to underestimate it.  So I think my analysis is very conservative in that regard.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How did you determine that the accelerations were less than 1.8g's?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So acceleration is defined as the change in velocity over the change -- or the amount of time required for the change in velocity.  So that's something you can find in really any physics textbook that you might find.  But in this case I utilized results from crash tests, previous crash tests, so vehicles with similar bumper systems, to determine that in my opinion this particular accident would have taken course -- taken place over the course of about 175 milliseconds, so just under two-tenths of a second.  And when you do the math on that, it works out to 1.8g's.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you perform any further analysis as to the severity of the collision?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, I did.  So I didn't want to just rely on the damage as described in the repair estimate, so I also performed what I would refer to as energy-based crush analyses of the vehicles, so essentially looking at how much crush damage there is to the back of the vehicles and identifying an upper boundary based on that.  So based primarily on specifications for those vehicles and photographs of the vehicles, and I performed that for both the rear end and the front of the 2004 Chevrolet Malibu since, as I mentioned, there was a report of a subsequent frontal contact, and then I also performed that same type of analysis to the front of the 2015 Toyota Rav4 and used the laws of physics to sort of calculate the subsequent change in velocity if that particular vehicle were to have sustained greater crush than it did in this particular accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did you perform the additional analysis?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: As I mentioned, I didn't want to just rely on one piece of information in order to come to my opinions.  So I, you know, the damage based speed change analysis, would rely somewhat heavily on the repair estimate for the vehicle.  I also wanted to use the objective information contained in the photographs of the vehicles as a part of my analysis, and I also utilized some of the available testimony with regard to vehicle speeds and motions in accordance with the laws of physics in order to just sort of check my work and make sure that everything was consistent with the Delta-V being less than 6.75 miles per hour for the rear-end contact.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did any of those additional analysis contradict your opinion that this accident resulted in a Delta-V of less than 6.75 miles per hour or that the accelerations were less than 1.8g?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No, sir.  They were all consistent with my previously mentioned opinions.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, with respect to this frontal collision, you are not offering an opinion as to whether or not that collision occurred, are you?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No.  For the purposes of my analysis, since the plaintiff mentioned it in her deposition, I went ahead and assumed that her vehicle did actually make contact with the vehicle in front of it, and then based on again the damage to the vehicle and the damage to the rear of the vehicle and the laws of physics, again established an upper boundary for the Delta-V and the accelerations due to potential frontal contact.  And in this case my opinion is any frontal contact, if it did occur, would actually have resulted in again a Delta-V less than 6.75 miles per hour and accelerations less than 1.8g's.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there any damage to the front of Ms. Perez's vehicle, the 2004 Chevy Malibu that she attributed to this accident?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: The plaintiff testified that there was no damage to the front of her vehicle, and the repair estimate did not list any damage to the front of the Chevrolet Malibu. The photographs did appear to show maybe some minor contact damage or scraping damage to the front of the vehicle, but certainly nothing that would indicate a significant frontal contact or anything like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, the third step in your analysis was to determine the kinematic response?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is a kinematic response?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So kinematics as a term refers to movement.  So in this case I'm interested in the movement of Ms. Perez's body within the vehicle.  And so in order to do that, basically the laws of physics dictate the general direction of her motion.  I wanted to go through and calculate various things like her seated height, based on her height and age and weight and sex and sort of determine how she would move relative to the interior of the vehicle.  So I calculated things like her seated height, and I also identified numerous clearances and sort of the space around her within the 2004 Chevrolet Malibu, and then I applied the laws of physics to this motor vehicle accident and verified the results of that analysis with motor vehicle or with previous crash testing, using cadavers or live human subjects. So basically in a rear-end type of collision the occupant inside of the struck vehicle would tend to move rearward, so toward her seat, relative to the interior of this -- of the 2004 Chevrolet Malibu.  And I determined that that would have been her general direction of motion. I also took into account the fact that the plaintiff testified that she was wearing the seat belt in the 2004 Chevrolet Malibu.  So based on the laws -- or based on federal law regarding seat belt assemblies, I determined that that seat belt assembly would have locked when her vehicle's accelerations reached 0.7g's which is the acceleration associated essentially with hard braking in the vehicle which is why you might notice that your seat belt assembly locks when you apply your brakes rapidly inside the vehicle. So I took all of that information into account and essentially determined how her body would have moved as a result of both the rear end and the front end collision in this accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So if I understand your testimony, Ms. Perez's 2004 Chevy Malibu was hit in the rear and pushed forward, but the occupant in the car, Ms. Perez, would have gone backwards?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, backward relative to the inside of the vehicle.  So essentially what happens in a rear-end accident is the vehicle gets pushed forward, and the net effect is that the occupant's seat sort of gets pushed toward their back.  So at the end of the day what that results in is motion of the occupant toward the seatback rearward relative to the interior of the vehicle.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that an opinion or is that physics?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: That's physics, sir.  That's well-documented in numerous scientific articles, and that's really the laws of physics that work in a motor vehicle accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that why when somebody hits the accelerator and the car goes forward, if they have something on their dashboard, it's going to end up in their lap?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir, the same principles at work.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that's why when you slam on the brakes, if you have something on the seat, it's going to go flying off the seat?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Objection.  Counsel testifying.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Yes.  So it's essentially, you know, if you're slamming on the brakes in your vehicle, the forces are acting in the same direction as if you were involved in a frontal accident.  It's causing your vehicle to slow down which results in everything inside the vehicle sort of continuing forward at the same speed that it was prior to braking or prior to the accident.  So it's all sort of the same -- same principles of physics at play.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What would happen to Ms. Perez's body if she --
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: I'm sorry.  You cut out for a second there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Strike it.  What would happen to Ms. Perez's body as she moved backward when the Chevy was pushed forward?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So sort of as a general direction of motion or a general motion of her body, I determined that her pelvis and her torso would have tended to move toward her seatback.  Her pelvis and her torso would have been well-supported by the seatback in this vehicle, and essentially her body would have just loaded into her seatback.  And then if there was any forward rebound associated with this particular accident, given the low severity and the low accelerations of this accident, I wouldn't expect a significant amount of rebound.  But as I mentioned previously, the seat belt assembly that she was wearing would have locked as her body was moving rearward, and it would have really controlled any forward motion of her body off of the seatback after she initially moved rearward. So it's my opinion that her body and her torso and her lumbar spine specifically would have been very well-supported by the seatback in this particular vehicle, and her lumbar spine would not have experienced any forces or motions outside of that associated with normal range of motion or normal physical activities.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, you mentioned also that Ms. Perez testified she subsequently came into contact with the vehicle in front of her.  What kinematic analysis -- strike that. You mentioned that Ms. Perez testified she subsequently came into contact with the vehicle in front of her.  Did your kinematic analysis also come to any possible motion of her body due to a frontal contact?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes.  So obviously if the occupant is going to tend to move backwards in a rear-end contact, her body would tend to move forwards due to any frontal contact. So as I mentioned, her seat belt assembly would have actually locked before she started moving forward.  So it would have been -- her forward motion would have been extremely well-controlled by that three-point restraint that she was wearing. I did take into account the possibility that she was sitting all the way forward with her seat completely vertically and performed calculations to determine how far forward her chest would have moved, and determined that if we grant the frontal contact and we sort of took into account the most severe circumstance for her in a subsequent frontal contact, if we assume any contact occurred between her chest and the steering wheel in this particular vehicle, it would have only occurred at a speed of about two to three miles per hour.  So it's my opinion that her forward motion would have been very well-controlled as a result of her locked three-point seat belt that she was wearing.  And again she would not have experienced any lumbar spine motion outside of a normal range or the normal physiological range of motion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We have covered the first three steps of your analysis; the injuries claimed, the severity of the accident, and the kinematic analysis.  What is the next step in the process?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So the next step after I perform the kinematic analysis, which is basically an analysis of the general motion of her body, the next step is to look specifically at the injured body part, in this case the lumbar spine at L5 and S1, and determine the types of forces that the lumbar spine was exposed to due to that kinematic motion or that movement of her body inside of the vehicle and to account for the mechanism of injury required to cause the injury being attributed to the accident and determine if that mechanism of injury was present.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How do you do that?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: So that consists of again sort of looking at my independent analysis and the severity of the accident and performing some calculations in that regard.  It also consists of identifying previous crash testing literature where those forces have actually been measured in comparable severity accidents and determining then based on the known mechanisms of injury whether or not those -- the forces in this particular accident were consistent with injurious loading to the lumbar spine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you come to a conclusion as to how this accident would have affected Ms. Perez's lumbar spine?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Objection, pending motion in limine.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Yes, sir, I did.  So with regard to the rear-end motion of her lumbar spine, as I mentioned, her seatback is located directly behind her lumbar spine in this vehicle.  And so any rearward motion of her body would have resulted in her lumbar spine essentially coming into contact with the seatback in this vehicle.  That rearward motion would have been very well-supported and all of the forces applied to her lumbar spine would have been spread out essentially over her entire torso.  And so really her lumbar spine in the rear-end collision here would only have experienced a limited degree of extension or sort of, you know, bending backwards very limited amount with regard to the rear-end collision. Now in any subsequent frontal collision, as I mentioned, her seat belt assembly would be locked.  And if you look at the lumbar motion associated with slight forward motion, it's again my opinion that her lumbar spine would not have experienced any motion outside of the normal physiological range.  And again the forces applied to her torso would have been disbursed over her entire torso due to the shoulder portion of her three-point belt. So it's my opinion that, you know, she would have essentially experienced greater forward motion bending over to tie her shoes than she would have in any subsequent frontal contact.  And her rearward motion or the extension of her lumbar spine would not have been significantly greater than essentially just sitting in the seat prior to the accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The shear forces, did you measure those?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: I didn't specifically measure them.  I did identify literature where it was measured previously at comparable severity levels.  In this case it's my opinion that the shear forces experienced by her lumbar spine would have been, you know, limited to about 20 pounds of force which is very minimal in terms of the lumbar shear forces that the human body can withstand. The bony parts of her lumbar spine that were damaged, the pars interarticularis, is not the only part of her lumbar spine that resists shear force.  You also have bones in your lumbar spine called facet joints, and previous research demonstrates that those facet joints can experience, you know, more than 650 pounds of shear force before there is any damage to the lumbar spine.  So in my opinion the shear forces in this particular accident were extremely low in the context of those needed to cause injury.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Move to strike the medical opinion. Motions in limine pending.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: With respect to the spondylolisthesis and spondylolysis, a certain amount of shear force is required to create those injuries?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did the amount of force necessary to cause those injuries based upon your analysis exist in this automobile accident?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Same objections.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: No, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: With respect to the G forces that Ms. Perez experienced during this accident, can you put those forces into some type of context for the jury?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So we've all heard the term G forces, but we may not be familiar with exactly what that means.  So 1g is the force due to gravity.  So that's the force that we're experiencing right now as we sit in our chairs. It's something that we all experience every single day. The human body experiences forces much higher than 1g during activities of daily living.  So there have been a lot of biomechanical studies aimed at understanding the forces and the accelerations that the human body experiences.  And one of the main reasons for that is to -- in order to design an implant or something that you are going to put into the human body, you have to understand the forces and accelerations that that implant is going to be exposed to on a daily basis. So the biomechanical community has studied the accelerations associated with various physical activities. To give you some context, if you were to, say, sit down quickly in your chair, your lumbar spine could be exposed to 3 to 4g's of acceleration. If you were to jump off of a step or jump up and land on your feet, your lumbar spine could experience accelerations on the order of 7 or 8g's even. If you look at something a little bit more comparable to sort of like a motor vehicle accident, as I mentioned previously, if you were to slam on the brakes in your car, that will be comparable to about 0.7g's of acceleration. And if you were, say, in a bumper car and that bumper car were hit very hard, you know, as about as hard as bumper cars can get hit, the vehicle accelerations of that bumper car could be as high as 4 or 5g's.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Those are far less than the forces involved in this accident?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You also -- the fifth part of your analysis, and I think we started in that a little bit, but the personal tolerance of Ms. Perez, what is meant by her personal tolerances?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Right.  So obviously everyone is different to some degree.  In this case I had previous medical records that demonstrated that Ms. Perez had a prior pars interarticularis defect.  So she had a fracture of the bony process behind her spine that predated this particular motor vehicle accident.  And so I wanted to take into account her personal tolerance, because obviously, as I mentioned, everybody is a little bit different.  So essentially that analysis consists of identifying the types of shear forces that her lumbar spine was capable of withstanding on a daily basis.  So I performed some calculations to determine just how much shear force her spine would experience if she were to, say, bend over at her waist. In this case, it's my opinion that her lumbar spine would experience greater shear force just bending over to tie her shoes than it experienced in this particular motor vehicle accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did your analysis account for potential variations in the plaintiff's posture or the posture immediately before the impact?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, it did.  So obviously there are always going to be certain things when you are performing this type of analysis that you can't know with exact certainty.  So I don't know exactly how her body was positioned inside of the vehicle.  And in order to account for that, what you essentially have to do is account for a range of potential initial positions of her body and then ask yourself whether or not, you know, changing that posture has a significant effect on the ultimate opinions with regard to whether or not the lumbar spine injuries were caused.  And so in this particular case I accounted for the possibility that, you know, maybe she was leaning forward a little bit, maybe she was straight up against her seatback, maybe she was turned to the side or something like that, and ultimately came to the conclusion that in this particular case those were not factors that affected the outcome of my analysis.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: With respect to the medical records you've reviewed, some of those were generated -- were some of those generated before the accident?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes.  Yes.  There was a considerable history of previous lower back pain and previous imaging of her lower back that I took into account with my analysis.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you also have the records following the accident?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you take into account her preexisting conditions?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Despite her preexisting conditions, is it still your opinion that this accident did not cause or exacerbate any of these injuries?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What are your final opinions in this case, Doctor?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Sure.  So in this particular case my opinions are that on May 28th of 2015 Ms. Perez was the seat belted driver of a 2004 Chevrolet Malibu that was involved in a rear-end contact and potentially a subsequent front-end contact.  The rear-end contact was caused by a 2015 Toyota Rav4.  The severity of the rear-end contact is consistent with a Delta-V of less than 6.75 miles per hour with average accelerations less than 1.8g's. As for the front-end contact or any potential front-end contact to her vehicle, that would also be consistent with a Delta-V less than 6.75 miles per hour and accelerations less than 1.8g's.  The accelerations that Ms. Perez experienced during this particular accident were within her personal tolerance and human tolerance levels and were comparable to or lower than those accelerations associated with typical daily activities. Her -- Ms. Perez's body would have tended to move rearward relative to the interior of the 2004 Chevrolet Malibu as a result of the rear-end contact to her vehicle, and that rearward motion would have been well-supported by the seatback that she was -- by the back of the seat that she was seated in, and she would not have experienced any lumbar motion outside of a normal physiological range as a result of that rearward motion. As a result of any front-end contact, her body would have tended to move forward, and that forward motion would have been well-controlled by the three-point seat belt that she was wearing, and again her lumbar spine would not have experienced any motion or loading outside of a normal physiological range as a result of that front-end contact. And then finally, it's my opinion that this incident did not create the mechanism needed to cause the lumbar injury that's being attributed to this particular accident.  And therefore, it's my opinion that the lumbar spine injury was not caused or exacerbated by this particular accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, did this accident involve the force or mechanism necessary to cause any injury to the lumbar spine?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Not in my opinion, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: So based on the laws of physics and the damage to the vehicle resulting in a Delta-V less than 6.75 miles per hour, it's my opinion that the defendant's vehicle would not have been traveling faster than somewhere between 9 1/2 and 13 miles per hour.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In that range; right?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Objection as to characterization.
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Well, somewhere less than that.  It depends on -- when you're performing that type of calculation, you have to come up with what I would refer to as a coefficient of restitution and accounting for a range of numbers for that coefficient of restitution.  The number would fall somewhere between 9 1/2 and 13, but again it would be less than that.  So it certainly could have been going less than 9 1/2, but it was most certainly traveling less than 13.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So -- so we are clear, it was a range between 9 1/2 and 13 and, like you said, it could be less, but it's still within a range because we don't know exactly; correct?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Mr. Wordeman, you also testified that you relied on some pictures in assisting you with your ultimate opinion in this case; is that correct?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Yes, ma'am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I think we went through this in your discovery deposition, there are about 116 pictures that you saw, some of them duplicates; correct?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Right.  Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know when those pictures were taken, either from the defendant's car or the plaintiff's car?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Certainly all of the photographs of the defendant's car that I have appear to have been taken in February of 2016.  I do not specifically know when the photographs of the plaintiff's vehicle were taken, ma'am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So the defendant's pictures would have been taken about a year after -- almost a year after the accident?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Almost, yes, ma'am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you rely on defendant's testimony that there was no damage and that she didn't take her car to be repaired; correct?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: I certainly took it into account, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But you didn't see any pictures prior to February 2016?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know if defendant on this case, Ms. Martinez, was at the scene of the accident when the police report was created?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: I believe, if I recall correctly, the plaintiff went and subsequently had the police report generated.  So I don't know that the police report was actually generated at the scene.  I believe it was generated subsequent to the accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So there is nothing in the police report to account to defendant's view of the accident; correct?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: To account for her view of the accident?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: For her -- yes, for her side of the story.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: No; I didn't see anything in the police report that would indicate that, ma'am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Mr. Wordeman, you did not review the transcript from Dr. Wahi's deposition, did you?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: I'm going to object as to form and characterization.  It was an evidence deposition.  He is not allowed to review that.
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Well, based on the objections, did you review any transcripts of Dr. Wahi's?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Same objection.
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No, ma'am, I don't believe I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you review any records from Mr. -- or for Dr. Wahi?
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: I would have to go through all of the records that I have to be able to tell you for sure, ma'am.  I don't recall seeing any, but that doesn't mean that I didn't see any. Could you spell the doctor's names, ma'am?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.  W-A-H-I.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: I don't recall seeing any medical records from a Dr. Wahi.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.  I have no further questions.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: ----- EXAMINATION
Doctor, why don't you look through your records from Midwest Physician Pain Center.
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Oh, here they are.   Oh, yes.  So there are some records from Dr. Wahi here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you did review and consider those in doing your analysis in this particular case?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You were asked a couple of questions about whiplash.  Is whiplash sometimes utilized as a generic term for acceleration, deceleration?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes.  I think that's generally what it is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is it also generic for sometimes flexion and extension?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And with respect to flexion, extension, is that something that you account for in your kinematic analysis?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes.  So, I mean, generally speaking, whiplash is not something that's associated with the lumbar spine at all.  It's more related to the cervical spine, but certainly the extension, the level of extension, the level of flexion of the lumbar spine are something that I accounted for during my analysis of this accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You were also asked about the potential speed of my client's vehicle which you gave an estimate of 9.5 to 13 miles per hour?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes.  The upper limit for the speed of defense vehicle would be somewhere in that range.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that based upon the Delta-V at 6.75 miles per hour?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Right.  It's based on a more conservative Delta- V than the actual Delta-V of this accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you would expect it to be less than the range that you gave?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In other words, that is a very conservative estimate?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Objection.  Mischaracterization.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Yes, sir, that's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you were asked about most of your cases being on behalf of defendants as opposed to plaintiffs. Do you limit your work to one side or the other?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: No, sir, certainly not.  I'll be happy to give a fair and honest opinion to anyone who seeks my opinions.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when we talk about the chest moving forward 182 millimeters, 182 sounds like a lot.  Translate that to inches for me.
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: It's going to be somewhere about 10 inches.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And there is, what, 10 millimeters to a centimeter?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: There is about 2 1/2 centimeters to an inch?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Objection.
speaker: MS. GROSS

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you are talking about 8 inches?
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Yes, 8 inches or so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, Doctor.
speaker: MR. FLYNN

text: Thank you.
speaker: THE WITNESS
